fxInfo_citation: Pemstein et al. (2018, V-Dem Working Paper Series 2018:21); V-Dem Codebook (see suggested citation at the top of this document).
fxInfo_clarification: Because discourse varies greatly from person to person, base your answer on the style that is most typical of prominent national political leaders.
fxInfo_cross_coder_aggregation: Bayesian Item Response Theory Measurement Model
fxInfo_question: When important policy changes are being considered, to what extent do political elites justify their positions in terms of the common good?

fxInfo_responses.value: Little or no justification in terms of the common good is usually offered.
Specific business, geographic, group, party, or constituency interests are for the most part offered as justifications.
Justifications are for the most part a mix of specific interests and the common good and it is impossible to say which justification is more common than the other.
Justifications are based on a mixture of references to constituency/party/group interests and on appeals to the common good.

Justifications are for the most part almost always based on explicit statements of the common good for society, understood either as the greatest good for the greatest number or as helping  the least advantaged in a society.

fxInfo_scale: Ordinal, converted to interval by the measurement model
